description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Cancer Daily-- Investigators publish new report on Oncology- Prostate Cancer. According to news reporting from Novara, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,“ We aim to develop and validate a new adaptive method for prostate cancer radiotherapy, using an off-line strategy to improve treatment...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Cancer Daily
\-- Investigators publish new report on Oncology - Prostate Cancer. According
to news reporting from Novara, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated,
"We aim to develop and validate a new adaptive method (O-ART) for prostate
cancer (PCa) radiotherapy (RT), using an off-line strategy to improve
treatment personalization by modelling the internal target volume (ITV) on
individual basis and account for the residual set-up uncertainties by robust
optimization. 20 patients with intermediate-high PCa treated with radical RT
were enrolled. The first step of the O-ART strategy is the identification of a
patient specific ITV based on the KV-cone beam CT (kV-CBCT) datasets acquired
during the first five fractions."

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from University
Hospital Maggiore della Carita, "The deformable image registration (DIR)
algorithm ANACONDA was used to propagate the clinical target volumes (CTV)
from the reference planning CT to the CBCTs; these contours were assessed by a
radiation oncologist. In the second step the ITV was used to re-plan the
treatment using a min-max robust algorithm based on the worst scenario
optimization. The CTV coverage and organs at risk (OAR) sparing achieved with
the robust plan (RP) were analyzed and compared with the original standard
plan (SP) calculating the dose distributions on the residual CBCTs. RP showed
to achieve optimal coverage of CTV even in the worst scenario and significant
less dose to rectum and bladder. CTV coverage of RP was statistically better
than SP in terms of D99 (p=0.008) and D98 (p=0.02). Statistically significant
mean dose reduction and D2 reduction was noted for rectum (p <0.05) and for
bladder (p <0.009). Moreover, RP appeared to be less sensitive to bladder and
rectal filling."

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This adaptive
strategy in prostate cancer radiotherapy is feasible and safe; it may be used
to adapt the treatment with better target coverage and OARs sparing than
standard PTV based planning."

For more information on this research see: Adaptive Strategy for External Beam
Radiotherapy In Prostate Cancer: Management of the Geometrical Uncertainties
With Robust Optimization. _Practical Radiation Oncology_ , 2020;():. (Elsevier
\- [www.elsevier.com](http://www.elsevier.com); Practical Radiation Oncology -
<http://www.journals.elsevier.com/practical-radiation-oncology/>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting D. Beldi, Division of Radiotherapy, University Hospital Maggiore
della Carita, corso Mazzini 18, 28100 Novara, Italy. Additional authors for
this research include E. Ferrara, J. Yin, L. Vigna, G. Loi and M. Krengli.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.prro.2020.05.006>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: New Findings on Prostate Cancer Discussed by Researchers at University Hospital Maggiore della Carita (Adaptive Strategy for External Beam Radiotherapy In Prostate Cancer: Management of the Geometrical Uncertainties With Robust Optimization): Oncology - Prostate Cancer
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Cancer Daily -- Investigators publish new report on Oncology - Prostate Cancer. According to news reporting from Novara, Italy, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “We aim to develop and validate a new adaptive method (O-ART) for prostate cancer (PCa) radiotherapy (RT), using an off-line strategy to improve treatment personalization by modelling the internal target volume (ITV) on individual basis and account for the residual set-up uncertainties by robust optimization. 20 patients with intermediate-high PCa treated with radical RT were enrolled. The first step of the O-ART strategy is the identification of a patient specific ITV based on the KV-cone beam CT (kV-CBCT) datasets acquired during the first five fractions.”

The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from University Hospital Maggiore della Carita, “The deformable image registration (DIR) algorithm ANACONDA was used to propagate the clinical target volumes (CTV) from the reference planning CT to the CBCTs; these contours were assessed by a radiation oncologist. In the second step the ITV was used to re-plan the treatment using a min-max robust algorithm based on the worst scenario optimization. The CTV coverage and organs at risk (OAR) sparing achieved with the robust plan (RP) were analyzed and compared with the original standard plan (SP) calculating the dose distributions on the residual CBCTs. RP showed to achieve optimal coverage of CTV even in the worst scenario and significant less dose to rectum and bladder. CTV coverage of RP was statistically better than SP in terms of D99 (p=0.008) and D98 (p=0.02). Statistically significant mean dose reduction and D2 reduction was noted for rectum (p <0.05) and for bladder (p <0.009). Moreover, RP appeared to be less sensitive to bladder and rectal filling.”

According to the news reporters, the research concluded: “This adaptive strategy in prostate cancer radiotherapy is feasible and safe; it may be used to adapt the treatment with better target coverage and OARs sparing than standard PTV based planning.”

For more information on this research see: Adaptive Strategy for External Beam Radiotherapy In Prostate Cancer: Management of the Geometrical Uncertainties With Robust Optimization. Practical Radiation Oncology, 2020;():. (Elsevier - www.elsevier.com; Practical Radiation Oncology - http://www.journals.elsevier.com/practical-radiation-oncology/)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting D. Beldi, Division of Radiotherapy, University Hospital Maggiore della Carita, corso Mazzini 18, 28100 Novara, Italy. Additional authors for this research include E. Ferrara, J. Yin, L. Vigna, G. Loi and M. Krengli.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.prro.2020.05.006. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
